Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Enhancing Comparative Assessment for Chemistry with or without Standardized Testing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In response to an increasing need for faculty members and departments to perform more thorough assessments of student learning, this project is conducting research on and developing tools to perform assessments of student learning in undergraduate chemistry courses. The overarching goal of the project is to provide chemistry instructors access to data warehouses of student performance on chemistry test items that can be queried to compare the performance of their students to the performance of the entire population in the database. This work is leveraging long-standing capacity in comparative assessment within chemistry education, as provided through norm-referenced examinations produced by the American Chemical Society Examinations Institute, with software developers, whose expertise led to the creation of the Online Web-based Learning (OWL) system used by 200,000 students of chemistry.

Intellectual Merit: Conducting psychometric research and developing semi-automated methods for instructors to align test items to a content criterion template are facilitating significant progress in both chemistry education and psychometrics. Specific project activities include producing an anchoring concepts content map (ACCM) for the entire undergraduate chemistry curriculum, creating a portal that allows chemistry instructors to connect and dynamically align their own test items to the ACCM and establishing a mechanism for instructors to compare the performances of their own students on their locally-written test items with national data sets of student performance. Developing the requisite software tools advances understanding in several key areas, such as architecture for test item meta tags, efficiency of test data warehousing, user-friendly query tools for assessment development and effectual data organization and visualization in assessment outcomes reports for users.

Broader Impacts: This work is developing practical tools for chemistry instructors from all institution types to improve their marshaling of evidence with regard to student learning in chemistry. As the database of student performance on assessments grows, data will permit for more complete and meaningful comparisons of the efficacy of curricular and pedagogical reforms. Outcomes from this project can be used to inform science education research across all disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Collaborative Research: Enhancing Comparative Assessment for Chemistry with or without Standardized Testing

 

Outcome #1: Tools for chemistry educators to carry out statistical analysis of tests

-       Early needs assessment for this project indicated that many chemistry instructors do not have access to statistical reports about student performances on tests, and some fraction of these instructors do not have training in how to generate such reports. For tests like those produced be the ACS Exams Institute with national databases of student performances, instructors needed additional tools to be able to best use the kinds of comparative data that national samples afford. As a result, several research projects were initiated in order to provide more ways for instructors to gain comparative information. To carry this out, methods for addressing missing data had to be researched. Some users of ACS Exams return full student response data, while others send only a final score (number of items correct), so in order to build item analysis tools, the differences between these two sets of data had to be analyzed and accommodated. This is the “missing data” problem, which can be solved using different methods of imputation (which is essentially a way to use data that is present to predict – and add in – missing data.) Once this process was accomplished a new tool was built to provide interactive spreadsheets (called EDAS) that allowed chemistry instructors to add or remove questions, or sets of questions, and garner comparative information between their students and those in the national sample.

Outcome #2: Refinement and expansion of the Anchoring Concepts Content Map (ACCM)

-       One key challenge of any four-year science degree lies in having a reasonable picture of the details of the content that students learn over the course of the degree. distinctions, such as organic chemistry versus analytical chemistry versus physical or inorganic chemistry, are arguably too broad for providing guidance about the content coverage of the four-year degree. Nonetheless, there are overarching concepts that appear in essentially any chemistry course. These ideas are referred to in this project as Anchoring Concepts, and by building a hierarchal map of the four-year’s worth of concepts organized by these “big ideas” chemistry instructors and curriculum developers have the opportunity to leverage a more nuanced and holistic view of the topic of chemistry. This project saw the refinement of the first anchoring concept content map (ACCM) for general chemistry, along with the development and publication of the organic chemistry, inorganic and physical chemistry versions. Work on the remaining maps in analytical chemistry and biochemistry is ongoing. The originally published components of the ACCM have already been used by instructors in various ways, and as the entire curriculum is organized and expressed in this manner, it is expected that many more chemistry teachers and curriculum developers will find them helpful in their work.

Outcome #3: Analysis of content coverage in general chemistry as reflected by ACS National exams.

-       In order to be able to use data analysis methods to align test questions to the ACCM, human alignment of many test items had to be carried out. This provided a training set and a test set of aligned items for the development of information retrieval methods described in outcome #4. At the same, aligning roughly 2000 test items from 20 years’ worth of nationally normed chemistry exams revealed patterns in what content is valued enough by chemistry instructors to appear on such exams. Some surprises, particularly content that was NOT tested, arose from this process. These potential omissions in coverage are now routinely provided to volunteers who develop ACS Exams, and papers have been published that point out the “holes” in concepts tested in general chemistry. This information can help curriculum developers address needs for change in what content is included in the general chemistry course.

Outcome #4: Information retrieval methods for aligning test items to the ACCM

-       While the organizational advantages associated with the development of the ACCM have been important, each map itself is fairly large, and can be cumbersome to use on a routine basis. As a result, a tool called QMAP was developed by the Center for Educational Software Development at UMass-Amherst, collaborators on this project. The QMAP tool allows a user to input a test question (or set of test questions) and be given most likely matches to the various statements in the ACCM. Having this tool available makes alignment tasks substantially easier, and thus enhances the prospects of people being able to use the rich organizational template provided by the ACCM in their own teaching and in their development of new and improved curricular materials.
